text: Pretty disappointed actually.  Family came from Indianapolis and Cicninnati. None liked any that we ordered. Seldom does that happen with any restaurant. Pretty surprised as Annapurna was definitely above average 2 years ago.

If you're looking for Indian street or south Asian food, then this is the spot. They have a good variety of chaats which never disappoint. Excellent quality for a great price. I always stop by here whenever I visit Devon. The dhokla is so yummy! Good & quick service as well!
Worst food I have ever had. Didnt know I am paying for stale food. Mutter Paneer was probably cooked 2 days back and still serving today!

Annapurna is arguably the best casual Indian restaurant on Devon Avenue.  And I will certainly be back to enjoy the full variety of their North-South-West Indian menu. You place an order at the cashier in the back, and then take a seat, waiting for your number to be called out when the food is ready.  Effective but not always efficient.  However, other alternatives will likely introduce chaos or require more labor--both with unintended consequences on the peaceful vibe and low prices of the restaurant. I tried the samosas, the vada pav and the Jain-style peas uttapam.  The vada pav came close to what one might find on the streets of Bombay, perhaps not as fresh.  But the uttapam was off-the-charts good.  For a restaurant that has such a wide range of Indian cuisines represented in the menu, they do an amazing job of combining quality, price and speed. If only there was a comparable spot in Manhattan, especially after Bhojan closed down.
The aaloo, in the masala dosa is the best one that you can find in Devon. The Chola, batura, was also good. Good service . Would recommend if you are in devon for dosa,

We came here to 'pre-game' for our Indian lunch on a saturday morning :) order at the counter, they give you a number and you go pick it up.  I'm pretty sure i'm gonna spell all of these wrong but: the pani puri and the aloo chaat were DELICIOUS! the crisps in the pani puri were fried nice and crunchy in ghee, which held up to the sauces very well. We ordered some potato samosas as well, but i wouldn't say they were amazing. definitely a crowd pleaser though. Seems like a pretty popular place for a snack and other little bagged goods you can pick out as you order.
The food here is about as authentic as you're going to get. The meal was good, staff were friendly, and the environment was welcoming.

I do not understand how this place has 4 stars.  First walk in and you can tell the whole place is dirty!  We ordered something and I asked the girl if it was made today. She says yes so we took it.  Our order comes out and it's dried up and stale and cold that I couldn't even cut it with the cheap plastic spoons they have. We had to return the food, take a refund and leave. Oh don't try using the restroom, smelled like rotting piss inside and outside near the washing area.  STAY AWAY if hygiene is important to you!

I've been going here since I was 7-8 years old and it's still my favorite dosa from all over the country. The staff is just super nice and the location is perfect with Patel Brothers next door. I've tried various dishes and everything feels and tastes like your grandma's cooking. Does it get better than that? Negative.
Affordable, authentic Indian and Pakistani eats.  You won't even miss the meat!

A vegetarian's delight.Very small scale and kind of home like desi food. Chat is great. Great vadapav and samosa paav. Nice warm phulke with fresh served sabji. Totally recommended if you want authentic taste.

Amazing vegetarian food in Chicago they're very friendly and quick customer service.  it's an in and out restaurant they have great prices for great food. I highly recommend this place.  I will be visiting very soon!

This was one of the best Indian food I tasted in recent Chicago trip. It's so cheap and you can try several things.  I tried dosa, thali with baingan bharta, mango lassi ... I know that's a lot of food, but we live in a area where there is no Indian restaurant in 100 mile radius.  Food was great!!  It's typical Indian street food.  Would love to visit again.

Though the  food is decent the customer service is non existent. We ordered dosa and choley barura. Even after 25 mins wait,  we didn't get our food and my wife went to ask the lady few times  and only to be told they are still making it.  When we asked for third time she checked with the guys making food inside and they told her you didn't tell us  about the order for choley  batura. It is not that  we didn't tell them because we paid for both of the food items and we got receipt and then waited to be called. We waited for ever in a fast food restaurant  and there was no apology . We finally left . Not going back due to pathetic  and non existent service.

Was trying to look for Jain options and called the restaurant to inquire for the same. Before I even completed my question, the lady rudely cut me off and said "No! No! We don't have!" and hung up. Clearly don't care about getting new customers. Thought I'd try the place because of decent reviews but, oh well.

Vegans, Vegetarians, check it out! I am a huge fan of authentic Indian cuisine, and Annapurna has a variety of excellent options to satisfy the hungry picky carnivore you might bring along with you. Thali, Aloo dishes, Samosa, Chat, Chana Masala, and Daal dishes fill the menu from top to bottom, and all of them can be had at a very reasonable price in either half or full orders. When I went, like almost always, I requested a variety of dishes to try, and was glad I did. Pro Tips: Order it to-go, and avoid the plastic and Styrofoam plates/dishes as much as possible. I was sad to see that such good food arrived with a plastic fork, so next time I'll do take out. Order extra rice, and extra naan - because I've found that it's always better to have too much than not enough, especially since so many of the dishes have extra sauce. Go at a slightly off-time - trust me on this one. Because everyone who visits this location also loves authentic cuisine, I quickly found that the small space fills up fast! I also went right at the height of dinner, (between 5-7pm), and it was almost standing room only. (Which is always the sign of good food.) Try a dish you haven't ever had as an extra. It's the only way to learn what your new favorite will be. Best of all, the walk down Devon afterward - it's a vacation unto itself! Namaste!

I'm not vegetarian but I'm in love with Annapurna. This is the closest I'll ever come to being one. I'm a Indian food lover and they serve thee best Indian food for a meat lover on Devon. They have the best chats around! The spices are bold and flavorful and their parathas leave you wanting more and more.. there chutneys have a blend or old meets new blend, to die for!!! There prices are the best! Generous portions and excellent customer service.  I'm too in love with this place already.. only downside is the parking, which I had to circle the block multiple times and found a park on a side street. It it's not their fault as Devon is one of the busiest streets on the north side. If you are a vegetarian and love Indian food, take a trip to Annapurna. You'll be glad you did!!! This is coming from a MEAT LOVER!!!!

Found ourselves on Devon Avenue one day and eventually the big question about where to eat. Too many Halal restaurants and many "is that even hygienic enough to be legal?" looking store fronts. Checked Yelp a lot and decided on this place. Walked it and it was heartening to see a place full of lively customers at that odd hour when it's too late for a late lunch and too early for an early dinner.  Tight quarters, busy staff and not the best seats. So why 5 stars? Well, it tasted like homemade cooking, nobody seemed to rush us (we stayed for well over an hour) and great bang for your buck. We were staring at each other in joyous disbelief when our food arrived. Totally hogged for the next hour and forgot that the food had taken some time to come. If you're a fan of Indian fare, they seemed to have done justice to both north and south Indian dishes (we're one of each). Portion sizes are generous and the ambience is very casual. You just gotta make sure you get in outside of "rush" hours as I imagine the place would be packed otherwise and worsen your experience.  Oh, and I didn't write the review for you. I wrote it so I'm not stuck on Devon Avenue ever in the future again trying to remember the name and/or location of this easy to miss gem. That should tell you something. If it doesn't, even better as it might stay under the radar and maintain its quality!
Good food with great price. Nice service too I highly recommend there dahi papdi chat
Great Indian chaat, snacks and stuffed parathas. Not spacious and shady neighborhood.

I took Plain dosa... it was extreme extreme bad...Seems old ... too much oily in taste.. plus it was burnt as well... I ate first tym it's pathetic.. I could not understand how can one make plain dosa so bad.. its so easy although
This place is delicious! The chaat was great and so were the desserts. Don't let the vegetarian menu scare you away.

Great veg and vegan Indian food. The service was a little bit in the not so friendly side, but the menu was great. They have a large selection of bagged snacks available as well. If I lived in the area, I would frequent this place often.
Yummmm... amazing chaats. Loved aloo tikki chaat. Bhel is great. I have tried almost all chaats on their menu. The only thing that I m not a big fan of is chole Bhature.

We really loved the Gujrathi thali.It was pure and pious as I and my husband fondly say. The food reminded of our home. We could enjoy the thali watching heavy snowfall through window. We ordered Faluda as well, it was not perfect, good though. I strongly suggest this place to vegetarians who want to travel in Chicago. This place is purna with taste.

After a long day at Devon avenue, I decided to pick up food for dinner. I wanted to eat a good vegetarian meal and this restaurant had decent reviews, hence ordered through Yelp. First of all, the prices are pretty reasonable. I got a lot of items in 30 bucks. I ordered dabeli, samosa, cutlet, dal makhni, malai kofta, roti, chhole bhature and pav bhaji.  Samosa- tasted fine, filling tasted good but the pastry was not crispy. Cutlet- these were aloo bonda instead of cutlet, I did not like them Dabeli- my dabeli had just two peanuts, very less chutney and too much onion, not good Dal makhni- it tasted like simple homemade dal but nothing like dal makhni. Still, tasted fine for homemade version Malai kofta- again not close to malai kofta you get in restaurants back in India but tasted fine Roti- soft and good Chhole bhature- tasted just ok nothing like you get back in Delhi For me, the food reminded me of an average home style cooking.
Staff is so rude and customer service is awful. Will not recommend. Prices are high and quality is worse.

Food is about as good as it can get for indian fast vegetarian food in Chicago.  Their service is quick.  It's not fancy.  We went on a crowded Saturday and it's the kind of place where you go to the counter, order, sit down - your number comes - go get your food - eat - and get out.  There is no ambience or reason to sit comfortably and savor your meal with conversation.  But if you are a fan of indian fast food you'll like this place.  I did.  And there are other places that offer the same options, but this is one of the better ones.  Kamdar Plaza down the street is a grocery store, but they also have similar fare and great food.
Excellent chaat! Highly recommend the aloo tikki and batata vada. Ambience is very hole in the wall but it's incredibly good chaat selection for the price.

Skip it. Nothing I or my friends ordered was very good. Went there because I was with a large group of vegetarians for lunch that needed to eat cheaply and fast. The dishes were bland/strange, and they were all staples of Indian cuisine that I've ordered at other restaurants and totally enjoyed. The prices are super reasonable, but still, if I'm going to Devon there are so many better places to eat.
The mixed chat was just great, and everything else as well. Samosas were fantastic and the Platters were awesome.
The food is really good ,we came here for first time ,I wish I had clicked some photos of food .We ordered Gujarati Thali,Kachori chat,pani poori & aloo paratha .The manager was very courteous.

The worst North Indian  Food I ever had in my life.. Dal makhni, palak paneer , Malai kofta taste was just yuk ..  Chole-bhatoore were  tasteless beyond the expectation... The Dhokla was good though .. Never go if you are looking for good , spicy Punjabi food.

Heard about this hole in the wall place next to Patel Brothers, and knew we had to check it out.  There is not a lot of fuss in the seating area. You order at the back at the counter and are given a number. There was so many people inside that we had to stalk out a table since the place was so packed.  They call your number when your food is ready.  We had samosa chaat which was hot, fresh with a fantastic assortment of flavors with the different chutneys.  The chickpeas were well cooked and great together.  The other thing we got was a masala dosa, which came with sambhar and a coconut chutney. Again, this was fresh and very tasty.  Lastly, I got palak paneer with roti and rice.  The roti was also fresh, and piping hot and was the perfect compliment to the palak paneer. The entire meal for 3 people cost us about $16 which is pretty good.  Again, there is not a lot of fuss with presentation but the food is amazing.

Have been coming here for over 20 years because the food is yummy! If you are expecting good service and fast food, not the place for you. One guy cleaning tables being pulled every which way.... You have to hover around seated customers waiting for a table... Their number system means nothing except to help them. Walking around the area afterwards realized there are plenty of other places we could've gone to.

Delicious food! A lot of the cooks in the kitchen were actually ladies from Mumbai, so food was true to the snack food of Mumbai streets, with a good amount of that Gujju influence (the dal is to die for). It's now my fav spot on Devon St. and I will be visiting this frequently!

Delicious vegetarian food! The chats at this place (Dahi Puri and kachori chat) are delicious. We also sampled the Gujarati thali, a weekend special. The rice, sweet Gujarati Kadi and vegetables were mouth watering. If you're in a mood for delicious vegetarian food - definitely give this place a try!

Every time we are in Chicago, Every time we want the most delicious Indian Street food & more, we head to Annapurna!  Fast, mouth watering chaats, dosas, dahi puris, vegetarian thali, they have it all! At extremely reasonable prices. Most of the time the owner is there and the whole team works really hard so that you have a great experience. You'll see couples, families with kids, parents, grandparents, everyone is welcome. Tables fill fast, service is prompt and now they have a wait staff person who will clear your dishes as you get more food. We've come here for years & will continue doing so!  Thanks to the staff & management there.. We normally finish with a paan & a masala chai to go!
Good for snacks... meal are awful... they serve Pita bread as Roti. Pro's : Cheap and neat clean Cons: Not such great for taste and Overcrowded

I went here with a couple of friends only because Uru-Swati was closed. The service was poor. The cashier was on her phone. When I asked her what she recommended, she pointed at two dishes on the menu and went back to whatever she was doing. My masala dosa was a bit greasy and the sambar was watery. My friends found their own dishes inedible and could only finish half their meals. I guess it was nice that the food was so cheap. We didn't waste too much money.

One of the best chat places! I ordered the sev puri and bhel puri. I had to ask for extra sauces and I like yogurt in all of my chats, so I asked for that as well. The staff was very polite. I came here with my 2yr old daughter, and they gave her some Indian snacks, and she loved it so much that I had to buy 1/2 a pound of it to go! I also took an extra bhel puri for my aunt; and she absolutely loved it. They carefully wrapped everything separately so it wouldn't get soggy. The prices are very decent and they have lots of seating. I wasn't a fan of their kulfi; but everything else exceeded my expectation; hence my 5star rating!
They earn my respect for their wide variety of chaats.  Come here to learn that there is so much more to that beautiful concept than just crushed samosas.

Excellent food with a crew that genuinely works very hard to make it right.  Veena and Salma are v customer focused and help you understand what's what esp with some of the lesser known dishes Don't miss the kachoris

Relaxed and casual, this place serves excellent food for a great price. First off, Annapurna is entirely vegetarian. I got a full plate with three vegetable dishes, rice and naan for $6.99! My favorite dish was the chana masala - probably the best I've ever had, followed by the palak paneer. The vegetables were on the spicier side, so order a lassi if you're used to milder dishes. We ended things with gulab jamun and a chai. I wasn't a huge fan of the chai but loved the dessert. Overall, the food was fantastic and we had a great experience.  You order at the counter then they bring the food to you. This place makes the perfect lunch spot - quick, delicious and affordable. We can't wait to come back.
Best food ever just like in India cooked the same way.. This place is amazing! They serve both South and North Indian food!! Inexpensive and authentic.

their pani puri is not good at all. both the pani and tamarind sauce are made from a powder, not the real deal. i would suggest going across the street to sukhadia's for pani puri. however their pav bhaji dosa is delish!
This restaurant has very good food at low prices.  I live nearby and is my go to "food to go" place.  Highly recommended.  Add to this the wonderful service and it's a winner.

Let first start out by saying that I do like their food and I have been going there for a very long time. I have lived in Chicago since 1988.  Today, I bought samosas and pani puri. First I paid for the samosas. Then I realized that the chutney (red and green sauce) that they gave me would not have been sufficient for us. I bought 14 samosas. So I asked for extra. They gave me extra . I paid for the samosas. Then I realized that I should get gol gapay (pani puri) for my dad. So I decided to order that. I bought a bag of gol gapay. Then I had to pay for the pani and chutney separately. She charged me the following (which does not add up): 1 Chick peas potatoes -- 2.49  1 Red/Green Chutney small -- 1.99 1 pani Puri (1Boul) --- 1.49 1 pani Puri (1Boul) --- 1.49 Total came to be: 7.45 Tax: 0.80 Amount Due: 8.26 I even asked the lady who was at the counter about the charges and she was not clear about the individual charges.  What she has done here is that she charged me for the extra chutney that I asked with the samosas with this order. That was very shady to say the least.  I am not saying don't go here. But check your receipt for the charges and also see how much they charge you for things. They are very shady!
Fast, inexpensive & clean. Vegetarian! Super. Raj Kachori to die for! Love the Dahi Papdi Chat, Masala Dosa and on and on. Cant get any better!
The most delicious paan, gol gappay & pav bhaji (right? Lol). Great little place for awesome food!
Best chaats n yummy dosas. For an amazing price ! The staff are hard workers n so sweet ! They gave me extra chutney since they I come once n a while

They have a variety of dishes to select from, and pretty quick service. I avoid too hot food, and they have the right blend of spices without making it chili hot. The only thing, they hv table for 4. We were a bigger group so had to settle on 2 tables, as they couldn't be joined. It's also self service place. But no complains there.  Do try raj kachori and dosa, absolutely delicious! 5 stars for sure!

Went there today and had the samosa chaat... It wasn't bad, but not what I expected. (Hence why I rated it 4/5). This place is always crowded, and for good reason! If you want a taste of India...definitely go here!
it's the place where I eat mostly when I go to devon. they have a variety of food and price is reasonable and quantity is good.

The first time I came here, they did not help with seating, so we left. Gave them a second chance a year later:  1- Service is slow 2- It's cheap, but portions are small too 3- Certainly avoid Pani Puri, not at all what pani puri should be 4- Their chutneys are mostly water with a touch of some spice! Definitely a big giant fail.  5- Dosa is average and Sambar is really poor quality.  There is a reason it's so cheap here! Items that I recommend are:  Behl Puri Samosa Chat Good luck!

$4.99 masala dosa, you can't go wrong with it. It was excellent dosa. Masala burger was ok, similar to we make it at home. All foods we ordered had an excellent taste. Don't expect  much service - it is self serve restaurant. But foods they prepare  are excellent and perfect destination for vegetarian. It's run by very friendly Gujarati family, you can feel taste in their food. Some of my south indian friend did not like dosa - as taste of traditional south indian dosa is totally different and most of other people will not like it.

My roommate and I drove 30 m in search of the best south Indian food on Devon Street and we were not disappointed. We got a masala dosa, paneer masala dosa, channa masala and bindi masala (dry spiced okra). The dosas were amazing, the spices were so fresh they were still bright green, and the sambar and coconut chutney that came with them were very flavorful. I really liked the channa masala, it tasted really fresh and healthy but was in a spiced brown base, not tomato (just fyi). The okra was good too, but very salty (nothing was lacking in salt). The mango lassi was good as well. The employees were very friendly and helpful. The atmosphere was casual/brightly lit, so not a great place for a date, but just great, authentic south Indian food.

They are from Gujarat - but they make all kind of food. They love Lord Krishna - if you like you can always say to Alpesh and his family "Jai Shree Krishna"  They make really Nice Dhokla..if there is a bulk order, this is place to be. Cost is so effective .. There is no sitting or waiter service but if you are prepared to go and pick up -this is the place to be. I had been there on October 30th October 31st  and November 5th 2015 I really like the way they do... Everything is Self Service. They call and you need to pick up .. Some days on weekends it is really hard to find a place.  they make real good food. They have a person later you can leave your plate there... One young guy comes and picks up. Name sounds South Indian but actually run by people from Gujarat - very nice , God fearing and God loving people. Would definitely recommend

This place has been around since I was a child. It's very nostalgic. After trying most of the places on Devon Ave, this is probably my favorite, it's cheap, its yummy, the portions for chaats are just right for 1 or to share! It's where I take my non indian friends to experience good Indian street food. I even approve of their dosas. Annapurna actually does it pretty accurately! Always fresh!

Went there after long time. This place has changed quiet a bit, nice hanging tv's which played some Bollywood songs. We ordered masala dosa, dahi puri and pav bhaji, Dosa was way to crispy and potatoes had no taste, pav bhaji was flavorful and gets three stars. This place is no frill however its okay food with cheaper price.

So good! We shared the samosa chaat and a thali. It was fast, tasty, and had such friendly service. (To that end, I have to disagree with the previous review that said not to go near closing time - we wandered in 20 minutes before closing and had nothing but a good experience.)

I saw this place on a list of the best vegetarian South Indian places in Chicago. It's very plain with no table service, but the food I had (Masala Dosa) was delicious. A friend and I both stuffed ourselves for less than $25. I would go again.

Tried the special gujrati thaali and really enjoyed it! Loved the buttermilk! The menu on a Saturday had black Chana and stuffed eggplant ( baingan) which I really liked. Came with a choice of roti or puri, rice, daal (sweet dal, Gujrati style), papad, salad, chutney. Snack that day was bhajji- I would have liked to have dhokla though.  I also got the masala dosa, which was good. But the coconut chutney that came with it want that great.

Annapurna  is a great concept. Good food from north, south and west. Any kitchen run by older Indian women will maintain certain quality and standards. The guy at the front desk is a bit rough but the service is food. Best place for Dosa and paw bhaji. Not to be missed.
Their Paneer Masala Dosa is super rich in flavor. I'm trying to come up with words to properly describe it, but nothing I write will do it proper justice. Go try it for yourself!
The food is extremely delicious. We ordered Masala Dosa, Samosa Chat, Aloo Paratha, & Chai. Nothing to complain about. The owner seems to be a real nice person with great customer service skills.

This is a solid place for vegetarian South Indian/Gujarati fare.  The sambar is solid with not too much oil. Basically, it's a workhorse; it doesn't really raise eyebrows but it gets the job done. I liked my uttapam, although it seemed a bit on the oily side.  I was annoyed that although the menu stated that the one I ordered came with green chillies, there were none.  When I asked where they were, I was told that I had to specially ask for it.  I don't know, if it's listed as coming with it, then I shouldn't have to ask for it specially. The chutney situation is kind of abysmal.  They only one they had was coconut, and it was totally liquid.  It should be pretty thick, more paste-like in consistency.  And they had no tomato chutney at all. Boo.  All in all, I think of this place as a good option when you want a simple dosa/idli/uttapam at reasonable prices.

The best masala dosa I've had in my life was in Mumbai.  The best masala dosa in Chicago is Annapurna ... perfectly crispy on the outside and perfectly seasoned in the inside!  Love the consistency of the crispy exterior and the mashy interior.  The coconut chutney is fine (wish the consistency was not as runny).   The menu is filled with my favorites.  There are a lot of great Indian drinks to try in the self serve cooler...try a dessert  LOVE this all vegetarian Indian restaurant!  Make a day of it ... have a dosa ... explore the neighborhood ... !
Yes... their samosas are that great! It is a great place for vegetarian Indian food and I would definitely highly recommend this place!
Love the reasonably priced food. The only thing that cost this restaurant a star is space. I wish the restaurant was a little bigger because it feels a little congested.

Annapurna does not have classy interior, or long menu. They have the best GUJARATI THALI in Chicago or east of Mississippi. I would say that anything else on the menu is just fillers. They have other options just like any other small indian restaurant but the best and only highly recommended dish is Gujarati Thali.

Amazing selection of south Indian vegetarian dishes that are not found anywhere else in the Midwest.  from the fried pakoras and samosas to this is the chickpeas and potatoes, tea, mango yogh drinks, deser and all sorts of vegetarian dishes
Their chaats are really good - pav bhaji especially! Their curries are a little bit sweet. Great prices though for good quantities!

I've been here so many times. I love the food. Love the spiciness. Lots of options.  They have loads of vegan options so they are aware of other dietary restrictions. Great place and amazing service. Very sweet people. Takes sometime for the food to come but it's worth the wait. :)

Food was good. I ordered chole puri, and my mom ordered chole bature. Both were tasty. I've eaten better puris but it was fine.  Compared to other small food places on devon, this one was pretty clean and new looking inside. Overall, 4 stars I recommend it!

The place is small, right next to Patel brothers, it's all self service, run by a Gujrathi family. The chat in this place was really good, I liked it. I had the Bhel Puri and the Onion Paratha, the latter was not that good. Prices are cheap here, so it's worth it.

Incredible selection of delicious Indian vegetarian cuisine for excellent prices.  The aloo paratha was exceptional.  They also have a great selection of interesting drinks and pre-packaged items in a deli cooler if you just wanna grab something and go.  The hot food food comes out quick and fresh if you decide to order at the counter and dine in.  I almost deducted a star for the beat up, beige plastic plates, but then I remembered that it's what goes on top of the plate and into my belly that really counts, and Annapurna puts  amazing stuff on their plates.   One of the gems of Devon ave.   Don't pass it by.

Cheap, yum Indian gujarati food! Love their weekly lunch specials for $3.99 - you get 2 rotis, rice, kadhi & a veg sabzi; amazing value for money!  Other items on the menu to look out for - khaastha kachori chaat, pav bhaji dosa, onion paratha and their weekend Special thali. Please don't order dosa/idli especially if you're a South Indian - there's no place in Devon that makes good South Indian food (Mysore Woodlands & Udupi Palace are utter CRAP). I'm South Indian myself & the only place where I can safely go to have a dosa/idli is the Balaji Temple in Aurora. Overall, it's not a fancy place but if you love gujju food, you sure will love Annapurna!

I like Annapurna for what it is. Good vegetarian Indian food for a great price. It doesn't have much ambiance as it is pretty much like an actual AC restaurant you would find in India, complete with a mostly Indian clientele. Dosas are great and the right price. I usually get a paper masala dosa, a samosa (95c) and mango lassi. Don't bother with the naan, but the curries were spicy and ok.

Now this is a good desi food place. Good pan as well.  Dishes i ordered.  Dhai puri Sev puri Aloo chaat  Samosa Mirchi bhaji.  Aloo tikki.  Chola bhatura.  Dosa. These guys have the best dahi puri. There chutneys are really good.  Dosa was amazing. Sambar was ok. The chutney is the key. All in all these guys make good food.  I wouldn't try the samosa or the mirchi baji. Ask them if they were made the same day. If not i would pass. They were tasty but not fresh.  One issue i had was that their place is clean but bathroom area is dirty even the hand wash area seems little nasty. It just needs a little attention. I hope they clean it soon.  As mostly everyone after eating a dosa and chola bhatura wants to wash hands and i wouldn't wanna go see some this that dirty after eating a good meal.  Last one is that i got a expired drink. I hope they fix that too. I just swapped it for a unexpired one.

I have been going to Devon Street since before I could walk, and for a long time, my family and I have our go-to spots which we know that time and time again are consistently outstanding. Annapurna is not one of them. I'm aware that they are supposed to be known for having your food super fast. But that's half the case and half not.  1) Either your food comes fast and it is a completely wrong order and not made correctly/doesn't taste good  2) All of your food takes forever to come and is halfway decent  or 3) One of your items comes out halfway decent and fast and you are waiting on the next meh dish to come that you ordered for another 20 minutes.  This place needs to get it together.  I ordered a bhel which was pretty tasty. It was good but nothing to jump up and down about. And I also ordered a plain dosa which took a lot of extra time to come out. When I finally did get my dosa it had potatoes in it, which wasn't a huge mistake, but a mistake nonetheless. I didn't bother trying to take it back because I figured it would take a half hour to go back and make it right.  Not. Worth. It. For good chaat go to Sukhadia's and for INSANELY delicious dosa/idli and South Indian food go to Mysore Woodlands. That's all.

Due to a migraine, I hadn't eaten much for the 4 days prior to ordering from Annapurna. So, I was obviously craving some extremely flavorful food. DO NOT order delivery. It took 2 hours for my food to arrive. When the food arrived I was shocked at how small the portions were, and the naan was actually a piece of PITA bread. I am a vegetarian and wanted so badly to like their food, but it was simply a miss. On top of everything else, the food was rather bland in comparison to many other Indian restaurants on the north side of Chicago. If you must eat at a purely vegetarian restaurant then be my guest, but all others don't waste your money.
I totally love it !!  After ages i felt like i am in India  Superb food amazing taste budget friendly cost !!  Love love love it

One of my favorite places on Devon street to have chat and tea. The owners are really good people. The staff is also very friendly.  I usually come here on weekends to eat their khamans.  The kachori chat, samosa chat and khasta kachori chat are must try. Chole bhature are also delicious. All said and done, they could cut a lil on the amount of oil they use. Just a little. Overall a good place to have some nice Indian food..

I really like Annapurna! The food is totally vegetarian and is vegan friendly. The menu is relatively extensive for the size of the place, and there are snacks galore at the front counter. It's not much on decor, but it's clean and the food is delicious and quickly prepared. Service was gracious and prompt. It's great!
They have nice Dosas and chats. They are in deed fast in serving. Only sambar is not that tasty like many other restaurants ;). But overall, a nice restaurant to have your lunch/ snacks.

This is the best food for the price u pay on devon street. It has become my staple every time I am at devon.  Love their dosa and malai kofta. Veggies can be a bit oily sometimes but they usually entertain special requests (no oil, less oil) for breads (Rotis, Nans etc.). The guy who takes orders is quite dexterous at his job. Finding a table to sit can sometimes be difficult, one time I had to share a table with a strange young man who was having a tuff time getting through a very spicy samosa chat. Even their washroom is clean and well maintained unlike some of the cheap places on devon.

We got so much delicious food for under $20! The vegetable platters are cheap as well as amazing. Staff seemed very kind and helpful. You order at the counter and your number is shouted out but what it lacks in ambience it more than makes up for itself in food quality. Wish I lived in Chicago, I'd go here all the time!

Delicious! Only vegetarian food, but it's so flavorful and spicy! The restaurant isn't very big, so seating is sometimes an issue if you come with a large group. I always get the chole bature when I come here, and it reminds me of Ambala Sweets in Cerritos, Ca. Absolutely amanzing.

I love the food. The dosas are humongous, the samosas are perfectly cooked, I love their chole dishes. The service is fast and there is always a Bollywood movie playing or some sort of music videos. I can't tell the difference but it adds to the ambiance. :)

Wanting to give negative stars right now. So I placed an order at 9:30pm today on grubhub. I called the restaurant with a question about an item i had ordered and no one picked up. So I callied again, and again one more time. No response. I thought ok maybe these guys are not wanting to answer the phone because its close to closing time. I then get an email from grub hub saying my food would be there at 11:30pm. Yes, very long but i thought who cares. 11:30 rolls around and no food. I try calling the restaurant and theres no response. I then called grub hub, they put me on hold to try and get in touch with the restaurant themselves and no luck. So, basically I placed an order while they were open and the food never came...and no one ever contacted be about it. WTF, this isn't India people.........and YES, i can say that I am an Indian. All I'm saying is that I better get some kind of discount. EDIT: Spoke to manager, very rude. Never took responsibility. After 10 minutes of bargaining he offered a discount in store only because he wanted this review taken down. No discount for delivery. I had to argue with the manager, would not let me even speak. This is how the customer is  treated...very nice. I wanted to work something out because I don't like leaving negative reviews, but sorry patrick you just weren't doing enough.
The food is delicious and cheap. The north indian dishes they make are really good, I just wish they could make a good dosa here and I would give it a 5 star. You always leave satisfied and full.

First we excepted for a good South Indian restaurant but I think it is best suited for North Indian dishes. The plates they serve are so used u can see the scratched surface while u finish the food. Also one more thing I need to address is about the neatness of the rest room it is kind of dirty as it in India I hope the restaurant owners make it better I ordered dosa, the dosa was good but the side dish sambar and chutney are so bad and I lost my appetite for food and stopped ordering further. Whatever is in the menu it should reflect the restaurant.
If you are a veg person and looking for a cheap meal this is your spot. I personally hate veg food but this was not bad.  It gets very crowded and dirty.

I went here twice because I hate giving negative reviews and I wanted to make sure that my first bad experience was not a fluke. The food is very cheap but I personally find disgusting. The classic masala dosa and sambar were down right awful. The masala dosa was ok but the sambar smelled as if it was burnt and was too watered down. I also wanted aloo gobi (cauliflower and potato dish). I saw the ladies in the kitchen microwave it. That was ridiculous! I wanted freshly made food. I did not know how many hours or even days prior the food was made. When I put my spoon in the aloo gobi, the food was slimy and when I lifted the spoon up, I could see slimy stringy things-almost like it was about to be spoiled. The second time I went there,  food experience was similar (no rotten food, just awful tasting).There are so many other vegetarian Indian Restaurants on Devon to try. Maybe I ordered the wrong things or maybe I went at the wrong times or maybe I am just unlucky. Whatever the reason is, I will never go here again.

My wife is a seasoned connoisseur of Indian food, and has taken me to a number of the finest restaurants in the city and we've been to Annapurna a number of times. Their issue isn't the food - the dosas are good, as are some of their other dishes such as the chana masala. The problem is with the people who are running the joint. On our last visit, the attitude we received from the proprietors was enough to make us vow never to return. Combine this with the fact that their mattar paneer is nowhere near as good as what you will find at Luzzat on Jarvis (possibly the best in the city!), and I was perfectly happy never stepping foot back in this place.  Never, ever call them for delivery or select them on grubhub. The food will take about two hours to arrive, it will be cold, and it will be lacking some of the essential components such as rice or one of the very dishes you had bought and paid for.  If you don't mind giving your money to genuinely hateful people, and are okay with waiting hundreds of minutes for your delivery, give Annapurna a try!

Before I moved to Chicago, I'd been going to Annapurna with my parents on road trips since I was little. The food is great for sharing and is almost like Indian tapas. I got a masala dosa, ragda petis, pani puri, and kachori chaat. The food was a bit spicy but so delicious.

With this name, my friends were hoping for a Nepalese place but even still, we gave it a go...we had chai teas, mango lassis and a 'paper dosa' as my friend calls it.   The price was good.  With a steady stream of patrons, our service was pretty fast (a little longer for the food.) Its not very big! So a crowd of 6 seemed to be a little squished but we made it work!  If I lived near by, I'd come back to try some of their other offerings!
Had a great experience here - affordable and pretty good chola bhatura which was what I was looking for.  Pretty typical chaat place and I would recommend checking it out
Absolutely the best Masala Dosas around and everything else was tasty too.  Very inexpensive too.  A great option if you don't feel like having a buffet or you are vegetarian.

The problem with all indian places on devon ave, is their service, EXCEPT THIS PLACE. The "uncle".. that's what we Indian ppl call other indian ppl that are older than us, who runs/owns this place is super nice. He is the only person on Devon Ave. who understands the value of good customer service. He is always super helpful and helps us with any questions we have about the menu. They have awesome awesome food here too. Its all snacky type indian food, but it is delicious. I'm not going to try to spell out any of the actual food items on the menu, even though I am gujarati, and probably should be able to, but whatever you try it's probably going to be good. They have the best meethi daal I've ever had outside of proper Gujurat, India.  They have also mastered another thing that most indian places can't seem to get a handle on - consistency. The food, staff, and service are all consistent. In this case, consistently good. Definitely hit this spot up if you are looking for fast and furious gujurati/south indiany type food. It's also clean!!

Can't quite bring myself to give this place 4 stars, even though the food is better than "good."  My break-down: Food: 3-4 stars Ambience: 3 stars Cleanliness: 2-3 stars In practice, there's very little that distinguishes Annapurna from, say, Gareeb Nawaz down the street.  But unlike Gareeb, this place doesn't feel like a prison mess hall.  The owners have clearly made an effort with regard to the look of the place, and given the general shabbiness of the competition, the effort is genuinely appreciated.  (The Indian music videos on view are really fun). But looks alone don't make for a great dining experience.  On the day I visited, the restaurant was busy, but not slammed, so the gruffness of the service (both at the counter and in the dining area) was a little disarming.  AP would definitely benefit from additional staff to help with busing and cleaning tables.  The one employee I saw performing these tasks appeared to be overburdened, and the cleanliness and orderliness of the dining area suffered as a result.  As for the food: the samosa chaat was excellent: great flavor, very nicely balanced.  I also really liked the mango lassi (generous on the mango), which paired nicely with the paneer dosa (crisp and warm).  I was less crazy about the bhindi masala, which was very heavy on the oil.  If the counter staff try to talk you into a platter combo (as they did me), be warned that the naan is nothing to write home about, and the "salad" is just a pile of tomatoes and onions, so kind of useless.  NB: "half" portions are pretty substantial, and the price is more than right. I'll be back, but this place needs a little work.

Everyone asks me where to go for the best Indian food, and I always have to go with Annapurna, although it does appear to be the biggest hole in the wall. But, let's be honest, almost every place on Devon is a hole in the wall. My family usually gets the following: Samosa Chaat: incredibly spicy and more "soupy" than one would expect, since chaat is usually a dry food. They add a little bit of a curry to the dish, but it is really filling and has all the components of a chaat. Masala Dosa: This is that looooooong doughy/crunchy item a lot of people see when they google "South Indian food". It is a similar taste/texture to the bread you get at Ethiopian restaurants, slightly sour and spoungy. The filling is usually potatoes and onions and is served with two different types of sauces. One is more like a soup, but you are supposed to dip your dosa into this before eating it. YUM. I feel like this is such a specialty because it's hard to make at home. Or maybe it's because my parents stem from a different region, so I only get this meal 1-2 times a year. Chole Bhature: This is a garbarnzo bean-heavy dish with a large circular bread. The bread has been fried so it's not the healthiest, but it is the most delicious!! =) They serve this with onions, jalapenos, and achar (pickled vegetables), so you can make it as spicy as you want. This item is definitely more of a morning breakfast/brunch item, and it's quite filling.  Chai: This is a black tea boiled (usually for hours!) with milk and various spices. They usually don't serve it with sugar, so make sure you get some before you leave. This is a real staple for Indians, as many people drink a cup after every meal.  They have a good array of desserts as well, so if you are brave enough to endure the sweetness of Indian desserts, then go for it. However, my personal opinion is that Indian sweets are very much an acquired taste so there's a good possibility that you will not like it the first few times you try it.

Visited this place again recently, and this was the only happening place on Devon on the Indian food.  For some reason, prices on Devon have almost doubled in the last few years, Dosa used to be 2.99, now it is 4.49, why would anyone come to Devon, there are expensive Indian restaurants right here in downtown. After trying so many things here, I can recommend that stick to the Masala Dosa, nothing else is fulfilling, may be Bhatura Chola is OK as well.  Tea is ok.  Chaats, snacks etc are all disappointing.  Place is moderately warm, run by warm people, who are overly eager to bill you for every little thing you get, it is better if they can bill at once, I had to get charged 4 times for 4 different orders we placed.
Authentic vegetarian Indian food. Huge tasty Samosas and the Thali was delicious !!!
Loved the food and chats here... I've been here quite a few times and always consistent in taste and service. My favorite is bhel-puri.. Its cheap and yet tasty.

While the prices looked great, this food was not worth the low amounts we paid.  Our delivery was late and the food was ice cold, slimy and unappealing.  The only good thing was the Faluda drink we ordered.  We'll never try this place again.

Went for a quick lunch today (friday). Very clean, bright atmosphere and I could see the ladies in the back cooking away. I asked about the lunch special, it was masala rice, and I paid $3.49 for a tray of spicy deliciousness. I don't even remember each little food part's name - yellow rice, a spicy tomato potato thing, coconutty soup, biryani rice, and mango lassi. Plus a side of what looked pico de gallo. Very good for the price! And fast, too. Counter service here, and a bit brusk, but that's very typical for Devon Ave. Well worth it for lunchtime or a quick bite.

Like Anthony Bourdain, I am not a fan of vegetarian food yet our exception is Indian food. Food is quick, cheap, and spicy and flavorful. Space is clean and decor is appealing to a young crowd. Really like that it's a cafe so you get to avoid the formal "dine-in" feeling.
Very authentic, Bombay Bhelpuri. Felt like home away from home.

This is a great spot for a lunch of traditional Indian food at a great price... and ALL VEGETARIAN!!! My recommendation would be to order their lunch special place where you can pick two entrées and they come with naan, rice and a little sweet treat. The portion sizes are perfect and the price even better.

Cheap, delicious, fast, clean, courteous,--pretty much firing on all cylinders. As soon as you walk into Annapurna the wave of spices in the air hits you, followed by the sights and sounds of Bollywood movies.  Decor is clean and minimal.  Crackers and prepackaged foods line the walls behind the counter, with a softdrink cooler over to one side.   Order at the counter in the back and you'll be given a number.  Sit where you like, and someone will bring your order to your table.  Even though many of the items on the menu are made in advance, you may have to wait 5 to 10 minutes. For the uninitiated, having a menu on the wall with pictures, or placing the buffet in front where it's visible would be useful.  If you've got a favorite spot for chole bhature you'll navigate things just fine.  If you don't know what that even is you may need to ask the lady at the counter for help, or wikipedia the menu before coming. High chairs are available and the place is generally kid-friendly.  For cheap eats, including some street foods and set menus from both north and south India, Annapurna is hard to beat.

I always loved walking around Devon, but hadn't found a place on Devon with as good of Indian food as we had in Artesia, in Southern California, or at VIc's in Berkeley. Annapurna is as good. It is half as much as most of the places on Devon and generally better. Go here.
Okay here is the updated review. We went again for a second time during a weekday and the food was consistent with what we had the first time there.  Yes, so this place indeed deserves 5 stars.

This place changed hands a couple of years ago. I haven't been back there until now. Prices used to be rock bottom but now have risen. It is no longer as crowded as it used to be. It certainly looks nicer. The dahivada was a pathetic imitation of the real thing, but that is true at most US establishments. Not serving a fresh dosa is, however, inexcusable. They had put heated filling into a cold pre-made crepe.

A small place that's sandwiched between Patel groceries and its cafe, this one's easy to dismiss once you spot it. But don't do that. Stop, go right in, and order a chaat or two. It's fantastic! Great portions and super friendly service. We've also tried their thali, and it's good! Fresh and tastes like home-made food.  Such a refreshing change from other establishments that have been around for years, that we've tried. Not that they are bad, but you just feel good about Annapurna. My husband and I have gone back twice in the last week.  The owners are happy to get feedback on their food, and go about doing their job smilingly. Here's hoping that that doesn't change. Cheers!

Came here for a samosa tonight - absolutely delicious! They insisted on having us wait 5 minutes for fresh ones, which makes all the difference; the crust was perfectly fried and flaky without exuding too much grease, and the filling (classic curried pea and potato) was a perfectly executed take on a classic. The best part? They cost $0.95, officially supplanting the Arnold Palmer as the best sub-$1 purchase known to man. An absolute must try!
I had a thali there.. Average price for average food in which I didn't really find anything worth admiring.

The positive is that its very inexpensive! The food here can be a hit or a miss. My husband n I are fans of Channa batura and select chat food (Indian street food) but most of the dishes tend to be on the greasy side that we dislike. The portion size is pretty big although, eating here can be a messy business 'cuz it feels a little filthy and very clumsy.
LOVE IT!!!! Dosa's are delicious. Chaat is delicious. Everything is just DELICIOUS :) :) haha can you tell i love this place. It is my favorite on Devon. I go there once a week. Check it out!

What up Yelpers, it's yo boyyy Jonny B!  I came to scope out this spot and it was straight bunk yo.  I didn't know what half the menu was, ain't lyin. I'm from chi-towwwwnnnn boy. we don't know lentils or masssahla. I asked for a cheeseburga and fries.  They didn't have that.  How can you have a menu that no peeps can read but you don't have a burga and fries? WACK  That's straight talk son on the realzz.  I was hungry like a mug up in that spot joe.  i got some curry which is like ketchup for a lot of peeps that ain't white.  That's culture for ya son, knowledge for ya dome.    Peace I'm out.

Annapurna is back on my good side. I remember back in the day (probably like 20 years ago) this was the go to snack shop on Devon.  I remember my parents taking me there many times.  Over time, unfortunately, I remember the place just deteriorated in terms of up-keep and quality.  I had been there a couple of times when I just felt like it was filthy.  Plus, other great options were springing up all around. Well, the other day we went to Devon and most of the other places were closed.  The place we usually go actually moved their closing time up to 7pm, which is strange. Well anyway, so I had heard that Annapurna had remodeled so I figured I'd give it another shot.  I'm happy I did.  So with the granite tables, floors, etc. the interior was definitely upgraded.  It's funny, but I don't know why casual fast food places on Devon think granite is appropriate for their decor.  Have you ever seen a McDonald's with granite tables?  At least never in the US.  Anyway, that's an aside.  It's just weird, because even with these upgrades, you can see how the attitude of cleanliness of this place hadn't changed.  Tables that had been used were left uncleaned and there was garbage on the floors.  Well, I won't be long before this place will become the dump that it was once again. Hmmm... this review is starting to sound more negative than I intended.  I guess the stars still represent.  Well, the reason for my good rating was the value for the food.  We got chole bhature for like $3.99?!  Crazy... and that includes two huge bhaturas, chole, chopped onions, pickled peppers, mango achar, and even some suji halwa.  That's outstanding.  Plus, when the chole ran out before the bhature, they willingly gave us more chole.  That's pretty cool.  Not only was this a great deal, but the taste was awesome.  Very Punjabi flavor, which was impressive given that it's a Gujrati-run shop. The bhel puri and dahi puri were good.  Not the best on Devon, but they were pretty good. Well, so Annapurna is back on my list of chaat shops on Devon.  Now, if they could only remember to sweep floors and clean tables more regularly.

I came in here with a couple of Europeans, who despite initiating this trip to Devon Street, didn't really know anything about Indian food, as far as I could tell. I give this background only to show how helpful the owner was in basically explaining the whole setup to them and helping them pick out a good variety of stuff for us all to get (had I been in charge of ordering, I probably would've just picked out more familiar stuff, I admit). I've had "chaat" before but this was quite different, as it was a nice variety of fried, mostly potato-based stuff. We also were able to feed four guys on $20 which is pretty remarkable (and considering I'd already promised to buy them all lunch, I was quite grateful for the price). I do think everything was a bit too potato-based, but it was all tasty and fun to eat, and I especially appreciate the hospitality from the owner!

The food is still unbeatable for the price. But...I miss the old Annapurna's. I know that half the reviewers on here found it creepy or scary and the old man grumpy, but you could fit an entire family in a booth (and I saw it done many a time) and the old man always ran a tight ship. Now they have these uncomfortable chairs, it feels like there's less tables than before, families can't all crowd in together, the service feels...awkward, and I stood at the counter for 10 minutes waiting for my tea. I should state that someone brought out a full tray of tea, set it on the counter, and then left without making any announcement as to whose tea it was. Turned out it was my tea, someone else's tea, and tea for three men waiting for a to go order. As I grabbed two cups (wondering if I might be stealing), I thought fondly of Old Man, who always held off on making my tea until after I had finished my meal. In an odd way, he brought a level of personalization to the service here, that now sadly seems to have gone. That said, Happy Retirement! You needed it. And also, nothing in the world will stop me coming here. Nothing.

On this pleasant early autumn day I decided to bike over to Annapurna for an uttapam.  As others have noted here, some extensive remodeling has recently taken place.  In ambiance it's gone from 1973 Los Angeles Taco King to... 2010 upper-middle-class Devon Street, or something like that.  I'll bet the other recently remodeled area restaurants (e.g., JaiHind) had the same interior design adviser. Anyway, it definitely changes the flavor of the place.  I'll avoid value judgments and let the reader have a fresh experience. As for the food, well, I've had quality commensurate with price pretty much every time.  You can get better food at numerous other places, but you can beat the price at only a few (e.g., Ghareeb Nawaz).  I'm a satisfied customer. Oh, and good to hear that the older guy just retired.  I was concerned about him, since he always seemed tightly wound.

I was shocked at the quality of food after reading all of the "rave" reviews on  yelp.com  .  Curries and breads were extremely greasy, sambar was bland.  The food just did not live up to the reviews here.  Very disappointed.  It was fast food but not good food.

I heart you, Anna Purna. This greasy, cheap vegetarian Indian food is seriously satisfying stuff. Strangely enough, I haven't had beingan bharta like that anywhere down Devon. Kinda mushy, but it's got this tiny bit of sweetness with the heat that is awesome. I'm a fan of the okra, too. On the flipside: not a huge fan of the bread they normally dole out with a combo plate: it's like the pita I get when I order Greek salad.  Another plus: Since they've remodeled, I haven't seen a single bug! Thumbs up to that. But I also haven't seen the gruff old dude behind the counter, either. THUMBS DOWN. :( My cash diet prohibits me from eating at "regular" indian places too often, so a thali or a veg combo priced in the single digits does me very well. That also means I can buy a big box of ladoo and enjoy my fat-assed-ness fully.
pani puri and dosa is great!  this is the spot for quick indian food on a budget that actually tastes good.  tastes just like home maybe even better =)

Annapurna is, in a word, amazing. It has everything I look for in a restaurant - cheap, fast, and delicious vegetarian Indian food.  The menu isn't huge, but they serve a lot of Indian food staples (appetizers, snacks, main dishes, and dosa), and everything on the menu costs about $5 or less. They also sell a variety of packaged snacks and desserts at the counter.  My friends and I tried the samosas, bhel puri (snack food made with puffed rice, onions, and spices), mattar paneer, saag paneer, and masala dosa (large crepe made with lentils and rice, filled with spicy potatoes). It cost about $17 and was more than enough food for 3 people. And it was incredibly tasty.  I heard from a friend that they've renovated, which has clearly taken place since most of these reviews were written. The restaurant is small but still seems spacious enough, very clean, and open. The walls, floors, tables/chairs, and everything else is obviously brand new or recently redone. The same friend (who has been here several times and brought me in) also told me that the crabby uncle who used to work the counter has retired (she asked another employee about him). And as always, the Bollywood music enhances the Indian atmosphere exponentially, and the accompanying videos make it that much better. I will definitely be going back, again and again and again.

It was my first time on Devon, so I thought I would explore a bit and get some chaat. Originally, I wanted to go to Sukhaadia's, but it was closed and under construction. Instead I saw Annapurna right next door and thought why not? It was okay and your average Indian fast food. The green chutney (sauce) could have used a little more tangy flavor. The service was also a little slow and disappointing. I guess the plus was a TV playing videos of the latest bollywood songs?

How I missed this restaurant all these days baffles me but I'm glad my friend discovered' it. Its authentic Indian vegetarian at its best and better cheap.  Have eaten a dozen times and my stomach likes it as well. ! Best fare: Samosas, ragda chat,  Masala dosa... And well for more spicy stuff the veggie curries. An ordinary ambiance and a senile grumpy old man are not obstacles enough to block me from my goal

This review is a bit late. I was here a while back so maybe they've changed. I was here when I was in the area looking for a sari for my wedding as it was right across the street from one of the bridal shops. They have yummy food for sure but the downside is the odd atmosphere and the service. If you can stomach sub-par service, your tummy will be in for a nice treat. Very authentic south indian food!

This is a dirt-cheap, bare-bones Indian cafe with decent food. Fluorescent lights, plastic booths and heat lamps are staples here so don't expect much by way of ambience. I had a masala dosa ($2.99) and a samosa ($0.75). I couldn't believe the prices. I have never in my life seen a dosa that cheap before. It took a while to prepare but it was done pretty well and made a great meal for a disgustingly low price. How does Annapurna make money on razor thin margins like that? The normal going rate for a dosa is around $6, which is TWICE as much as Annapurna charges. While the dosa was pretty well done and came with sambar and chutney, the samosa wasn't that great. It had a weird taste, the texture was too soft, and the shape was too flat. Samosas should be pyramidal, crispy on the outside, and starchy-dry on the inside. That said, for $0.75 I guess it wasn't that bad. Annapurna also sells some Indian desserts, such as cashew rolls and almond triangle-things which appear to be vegan, based on the ingredients label. Best to ask questions, though, as one of the "natural flavors" was not elaborated upon; while I doubt it would be a milk or animal product, you never know. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, as the Devon corridor is isolated and difficult to get to without a car, but if you happen to be on Devon and are looking for cheap food, this is a good spot.

I gave a three star for the price and food. One star for the cleanliness. Customer service is okay. The cashier looks like he is dead. That's the comment my fiancee made. It is hard to understand what he says. For less than $10 you can get a whole lot of food at this place. The store is located right across from the fancy looking Sahil Boutique. They have all kind of South Indian food ranging from idli, masala dosa, vada, paani poori, etc. Their vada is really huge compared to the ones I had eaten in India. I could not take more than 2 sips of their limca.  Even though I gave a 3 star for this place I would suggest you to give it a try because of the food. You would love it if you are a fan of South Indian food. Don't get intimidated by the old man at the register.

This place food is very reasonable. Their masala dosa and vada are really good.This place is not that  clean l. I always have take out from this place. Their chutney get spoil very quckly.But  this place is ok.
This is the place to go for authentic Indian street food.  No frills here.  I'm Indian and this is by far my favorite Indian food joint in Chicago.

Oh yum, Annapurna!  A recent discovery (big thank-you to friend Sheila for being my ultimate Devon guru!) has turned into a very big crush.  This isn't an Indian buffet or a local curry joint, it's authentic Indian street food and sweets.  The decor is nothing to write home about, but it's all about the food, people!  And did I mention it's ALL vegetarian?  Oh, my happy place. This place isn't recommended for first-time Indian food diners because the menu doesn't explain what any of the food is.  Know your Indian cuisine?  I loved the pani puri, the masala dosa, the papdi chat, and anything that comes with the bhatura.  The snacks are better than the full meals.  The mango lassi was delicious as always, and the cashew-pistachio sweet rolls are a nice take-home treat. Annapurna is also cheap, cheap, cheap.  A huge brunch meal for five people was under $30, total.  The man who works behind the counter isn't as intimidating as he may seem!  I've even gotten a smile once or twice.

Ok, the cashier/owner guy is a bit of a grump, but at these prices, it's worth it.  Sure, the menu is not really explanatory, but if it's all veg, just order something.  It's not like it could be intestines or anything. The only thing was that my samosas were cold.  I don;t care for cold food at all, so they lost a star for that. And FYI, the mango juice that's so cheap is the size of a juice box.  Probably still worth it. But since it's cheep, i'll be back.

This place is the best. Its so cheap! And so yummy. And vegetarian! Need I go on? (= I can't ever understand what the guy behind the counter is saying, but that doesn't make the food any less yummy. So for vegetarians who want [fast] Indian food, give it a try!

The great: It's cheap! The OK: The food itself. My main meal was a masala dosa, a crepe made of fermented rice and lentils, and stuffed with spicy potato and onions.  I have had better but at nowhere near the same price. My favorite part of the meal was the vada, fried lentil donuts accompanied by a coconut sambol. The not-so-good: The décor.  Anapurna, with blue bench seating and cracked laminate flooring, has the feel of a run down fast food restaurant.   The scary: The grumpy old man behind the counter.  When I placed my order he mumbled something.  That I didn't understand him seemed to aggravate him even more.  While awaiting my meal I enjoyed watching the confused looks on the faces of other patrons as the old man announced orders over his PA system.  Dinner and a show. Will I be back? Probably.  The cheap meal/entertainment are difficult to pass up.

Annapurna is as close to Indian street vendor food as it can get. The food won't blow your mind away, but it's ridiculously cheap. Actually, I wouldn't recommend the "entrees" like Mutter Paneer (though it's tempting at $2.99 for a combo). Stick to the appetizers and you'll be alright. (Mmm, idli sambar.) The old man/cashier is extremely, extremely difficult to understand. There is no description of dishes, so first timers may have troubles deciding what to order. The food takes a while to come out, especially on weekends. Overall, Annapurna offers no thrills Indian fast food with everything being under $4 (no lie). NOTE: They are CLOSED on TUESDAYS.

This palace is the McDonalds of Indian snacks. Yes, its a fast food place. And no, they are not great at it. Just average. Cheap, quick, and satisfying. For a little more authentic tasting fare, I recommend going across the street to Sukhadia's. Sukhadia's service SUCKS, but they have better tasting sambar, and even better tasting chaats 'n snacks. I agree with previous reviewer that Annapurna could up its taste and quality by 50% or more.

Devon is a wonderful place - full of restaurants that offer cheap treats and tasty food; well there are some higher priced ones. Anyway, when it comes to cheap "treats" this one was cheap - getting a meal for two for $6.85; can't beat that, right? Well, enough good about this place - now the real dish about this place. It's the worst food I've had on the planet. I went there got a regular thali. Ate it - fully dissatisfied as it was cooked three days ago. Went home, puked. Apparently, the people I was with suffered the same - even worse.  If you feel the need to go to this place; please, spare yourself. If you want to go to this place, call me or email me, I will pay you to go to an 'ok' place like Tahoora.

Great Indian fast food.  I love that it's all veggie and the music is also authentic and enjoyable.  I used to live much closer and this is one of the places I miss most.  It's definitely on the dive end of Devon but incredibly reasonably priced and exceptionally great if you want something quick and you want to try different Indian dishes and snacks. Mango lassis are also great!

I've been coming here for 10 years and I don't think it hasn't changed a bit.  I think if it did, it just wouldn't be the same - terrible decor, prickly owner (he takes your order and works the cash register, and is generally impatient about hemming and hawing).. but super good, super cheap south indian fare.  The last time I was here, I explained the menu to two young indie-20-somethings, and tried to emphasize how big the portions were (despite the $3-4 prices) - they didn't believe me and ended up with enough food for 4 or 6 people, on $20!  The other caveat is that you should know what the dishes are before you go, since there is pretty much no explanation on the board above the food prep.. Also, dosas and bhel puri are best eaten fresh, so brave the cafeteria/fast food type tables, get a mango juice (carbonation doesn't help with spicy food), and go on a cool day (hot day +hot food +warm restaurant = hard on your digestion!)  The samosas and indian sweets travel well though!  I always get extra for snacking at home

Best samosas I've ever had.  If you're freaked about about the cashier/owner, don't be discouraged, especially if you're not of South Asian descent.  Become a regular customer and he'll remember and open up to you.  Minus one star because although it appears that they have passed all inspections, the dining area just looks like it will never be clean.  The menus don't have English translations, but once you know what you want, you should be in and out in about five to ten minutes.

This place takes me back to the good ol' chaat joints in India. Food's really yummy - its not the romantic place by any means or even a place to have a nice social dinner, you go there to eat 'n that's it..for those who are not used to the kind of decor in there, it could feel a bit weird..but well if you're not used to that decor, well this might be a totally different story. Especially on cold winter nights, I yearn for some of the nice spicy bhel puri and hot chai..'n as good as the food is, the prices are even better..really worth the buck..if only this joint was a stone's throw away.

Delicious veg snacks! Went here today, and threw caution to the wind, ordered two things that I had no idea what they were. My friend played it safe, and ordered samosas, but she loved 'em. I got Dal Wada and Kochari (think that's how it's spelled). Little fried balls of goodness . . . Not the cleanest joint, but that bothers me . . . not at all!

I only got the samosas to accompany my own Indian meal at home but they were delicious!!  Probably the best samosa I've had in Chicago.  I would have given it five stars but the sauce they gave with is was weak!  I went to go buy chutneys at the grocery store for more flavor. But yeah I feel they do treat you a little differently since I'm not of Indian descent.  But I don't hold it against them.  It's their culture and own experience.  I'm sure they've had the some racial experience sometime in their lives that make them so cautious. Yummy!!  Go get a samosa now!

I'm surprised that I haven't reviewed this place yet. Today I went with a group of four and all of us feasted for less than $20 total. Their samosas are delicious and only 65 cents. Anyway, this place is a kind of hole-in-the-wall type of place that is frequented almost exclusively by people who actually speak Hindi. The menu doesn't have translations of the different dishes are, so you can just kind of guess and order dosi, roti, chana, aloo gobi, and you can generally be assured that it will be delicious whatever you choose. Everything is vegetarian here, and it's all very inexpensive, fast food. You order from a counter, choose a blue formica table and wait for your number to be called, get your food, feast, bus your own table and then go. Easy, filling and simple. This place is no-frills, unglamorous, but a great place to stop in for a quick bite to eat.
